sen.j: 天皇が大王 (ヤマト王権)（おおきみ）と呼ばれていた古墳時代には、その陵は巨大な前方後円墳であった（9代開化陵～30代敏達陵）。
sen.e: During Kofun period (tumulus period) when the emperor was called Okimi (Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty)), the mausoleum was a giant keyhole-shaped tomb mound (from Mausoleum of Emperor Kaika, the ninth to that of Emperor Bidatsu, the thirtieth).

During Kofun period (tumulus period) when the emperor was called Okimi (Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty)), the mausoleum was a giant keyhole-shaped tomb mound (from Mausoleum of Emperor Kaika, the ninth to that of Emperor Bidatsu, the thirtieth).

During the Tumulus period, when emperors were called "Great Kings" ("okimi" in Japanese) in the Yamato kingdom, an emperor's tumulus was built in a circular shape with a rectangular frontage (from the tumulus of Kaika, the ninth emperor to that of Bidatsu, the thirtieth emperor).

sen.j: 7世紀になり、ヤマト王権が大陸の政治システムの影響を受けるようになると大型の方墳、円墳へと変化し、さらに7世紀中頃から8世紀初頭まで天皇陵には八角墳が採用されるようになる（舒明陵の段ノ塚古墳、天智陵の御廟野古墳、天武・持統合葬陵の野口王墓、文武陵の中尾山古墳）。
sen.e: After the seventh century, when Yamato sovereignty was affected by the political system of the mainland, the mausoleum was changed to large square tumulus and a round barrow, and during the mid seventh century to the early eighth century, Hakkaku-fun Tumulus was adopted to the imperial mausoleum (Dannozuka-kofun Tumulus of Emperor Jomei Mausoleum, Gobyono-kofun Tumulus of Emperor Tenchi Mausoleum, Noguchino Ono-haka Tumulus of Emperor Tenmu Mausoleum where Empress Jito buried together, and Nakaoyama-kofun Tumulus of Emperor Monmu Mausoleum).

After the seventh century, when Yamato sovereignty was affected by the political system of the mainland, the mausoleum was changed to a large square tumulus and a round barrow, and during the mid seventh century to the early eighth century, Hakkaku-fun Tumulus was adopted to the imperial mausoleum (Dannozuka-kofun Tumulus of Emperor Jomei Mausoleum, Gobyono-kofun Tumulus of Emperor Tenchi Mausoleum, Noguchino Ono-haka Tumulus of Emperor Tenmu Mausoleum where Empress Jito buried together, and Nakaoyama-kofun Tumulus of Emperor Monmu Mausoleum).

In the 7th century, when the Yamato kingdom came under the influence of the political system of the Chinese continent, emperors' tumuli came to be built in a large rectangular or round shape, and from the mid-7th to early 8th centuries, in an octagonal shape (e.g. Dannozuka Tumulus of Emperor Jomei, Gobyono Tumulus of Emperor Tenchi, Noguchino Imperial Tumulus of Emperor Tenmu and Empress Jito, and Nakaoyama Tumulus of Emperor Monmu).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: このような特別な八角墳が大王にのみ採用されたのは、畿内を中心とした首長連合の盟主であった大王の地位を、一般の首長を超越して中国の天子のような唯一の最高権力者として地位を確立しようとして形に表したという解釈がある。
sen.e: There was an interpretation that the reason for this kind of special Hakkaku-fun Tumulus to be adopted to the mausoleum for Okimi was to physicalize the post of Okimi who was a leader of chief association mainly in Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) in order to established the post as a unique person in paramount authority such as a Chinese emperor rising above a common chief.

Some interpret that the reason for this kind of special Hakkaku-fun Tumulus to be adopted to the mausoleum for Okimi was to physicalize the post of Okimi who was a leader of chief association mainly in Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) in order to established the post as a unique person in paramount authority such as a Chinese emperor rising above a common chief.

Some people argue that these octagonal tumuli, which were built only for Great Kings, were built as symbols designed to establish the status of these kings, who led the union of chiefs in and around the Kinai region (region around Kyoto and Nara), as supreme rulers like Chinese emperors ranking far above other ordinary chiefs.

sen.j: 奈良時代から平安時代初頭にかけての天皇陵は、土葬される例（聖武天皇）や、墳丘を作ったと思われる事例（桓武天皇）を経て、仏教思想の影響により、火葬の導入（持統天皇）や火葬後に散骨して大規模な造営を行わない事例（嵯峨天皇、淳和天皇）などが見られるようになる。
sen.e: For the imperial mausoleums from Nara period to the early Heian period, there were some cases where burial was adopted (Emperor Shomu's case) and some cases where grave mounds were built (Emperor Kanmu's case), and after that, adoption of cremation (Empress Jito' case) and scattering of ashes after cremation without large-scale building (the cases of Emperor Saga and Emperor Junna) have been visible.

For the imperial mausoleums from Nara period to the early Heian period, there were some cases where burial was adopted (Emperor Shomu's case) and some cases where grave mounds were built (Emperor Kanmu's case), and after that, adoption of cremation (Empress Jito' case) and scattering of ashes after cremation without large-scale building (the cases of Emperor Saga and Emperor Junna) have been visible.

Mausoleums built from the Nara to the early Heian periods include graves of emperors (e.g. Emperor Shomu) whose bodies were buried, graves with burial mounds (Emperor Kanmu), graves of emperors in later periods (Empress Jito) whose bodies were cremated due to the influence of Buddhism and graves of cremated emperors that were built without large-scale construction work (Emperors Saga and Junna).

sen.e: At the time of Emperor Shirakawa in cloister government period, a method to place ashes in the main hall of Buddhist-style was appeared and imperial mausoleums of stone tower-style were built in Sennyu-ji Temple in Kyoto after the Emperor Gomizuno in Edo period.

During the period of the cloister government by Emperor Shirakawa, a new funeral style was adopted, in which the ashes of a deceased person were placed in a Buddhist chapel, and during the Edo period, tower-shaped stone graves were built at Senyu-ji Temple in Kyoto for the emperors after Emperor Gomizuno.
